title: Advanced Computer Architecture Quiz
description: Quiz covering advanced computer architecture concepts.

questions.text: What is the primary characteristic of RISC (Reduced Instruction Set Computing) architecture?
questions.explanation: RISC architectures are characterized by a reduced set of instructions, typically with fixed-length instructions.

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic of CISC (Complex Instruction Set Computing) architecture?
questions.explanation: CISC architectures typically have memory-to-memory operations and variable-length instructions.

questions.text: SPARC architecture is based on CISC.
questions.explanation: SPARC (Scalable Processor Architecture) is based on RISC.

questions.text: What does the term 'endianness' refer to in computer architecture?
questions.explanation: Endianness refers to the order in which bytes of a multi-byte data type are stored in memory.

questions.text: In a big-endian system, which byte of a multi-byte data type is stored at the lowest memory address?
questions.explanation: In a big-endian system, the most significant byte (MSB) is stored at the lowest memory address.

questions.text: x86 architectures allow more than 4GB of RAM to be installed.
questions.explanation: x86 architectures are limited to a maximum of 4GB of RAM. x64 architectures allow more than 4GB of RAM.

questions.text: Which of the following is a benefit of using pipelining in CPU architecture?
questions.explanation: Pipelining increases the throughput of instructions by overlapping their execution.

questions.text: What is the purpose of branch prediction in CPU architecture?
questions.explanation: Branch prediction attempts to guess the outcome of a conditional branch instruction to avoid pipeline stalls.
correctAnswers: Guess the outcome of branch instructions

questions.text: Superscalar architecture refers to the ability to execute instructions out of order.
questions.explanation: Superscalar architecture refers to the ability to execute multiple instructions in parallel.

questions.text: What is the purpose of a memory management unit (MMU)?
questions.explanation: A memory management unit (MMU) manages memory access and provides virtual memory capabilities.
correctAnswers: Manage memory access and virtual memory

questions.text: Which level of cache memory is typically the fastest and smallest?
questions.explanation: L1 cache is typically the fastest and smallest cache memory level.

questions.text: Cache memory is slower than RAM.
questions.explanation: Cache memory is faster than RAM.

questions.text: What is the purpose of Direct Memory Access (DMA)?
questions.explanation: Direct Memory Access (DMA) allows peripherals to access system memory directly without involving the CPU.
correctAnswers: Allow peripherals to access memory directly

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic of multi-core processors?
questions.explanation: Multi-core processors have multiple processing units on a single chip.
correctAnswers: Multiple processing units on a single chip

questions.text: Hyper-threading doubles the number of physical cores in a CPU.
questions.explanation: Hyper-threading allows a single physical core to behave like two logical cores, but it does not double the number of physical cores.

questions.text: What is the purpose of SIMD (Single Instruction, Multiple Data) instructions?
questions.explanation: SIMD instructions allow a single instruction to operate on multiple data points simultaneously.
correctAnswers: Operate on multiple data points simultaneously

questions.text: Which of the following is a type of memory?
questions.explanation: SRAM (Static RAM) is a type of memory.

questions.text: DRAM is faster than SRAM.
questions.explanation: SRAM (Static RAM) is faster than DRAM (Dynamic RAM).

questions.text: What is the purpose of Non-Uniform Memory Access (NUMA)?
questions.explanation: NUMA is a memory access architecture designed for multiprocessor systems where memory access time depends on the memory location relative to a processor.

questions.text: What is the function of the Arithmetic Logic Unit (ALU) in a CPU?
questions.explanation: The Arithmetic Logic Unit (ALU) performs arithmetic and logical operations.

questions.text: Which of the following architectures uses a purely big-endian approach?
questions.explanation: SPARC architecture uses a purely big-endian approach.

questions.text: Which of the following architectures is based on CISC computing?
questions.explanation: x86 architecture is based on CISC computing.

questions.text: What is the maximum amount of RAM that can be installed in a typical x86 system?
questions.explanation: No more than 4 GB of RAM allowed to be installed in x86 systems.

questions.text: Which of the following architectures is purely little-endian?
questions.explanation: x86 architecture is purely little-endian.
